column1: Head and face reconstruction is surgery to repair or reshape deformities of the head and face (craniofacial).
Some of the bones of the face are cut and moved.
Pieces of bone (bone grafts) may be taken from the pelvis, ribs, or skull to fill in spaces where bones of the face and head were moved.
To cover the holes, flaps may be taken from the hand, buttocks, chest wall, or thigh.
Sometimes the surgery causes swelling of the face, mouth, or neck, which may last for weeks.
This is a small hole that is made in your neck through which a tube (endotracheal tube) is placed in the airway (trachea).

Craniofacial reconstruction may be done if there are: - Birth defects and deformities from conditions such as cleft lip or palate, craniosynostosis, Apert syndrome - Deformities caused by surgery done to treat tumors - Injuries to the head, face, or jaw - Tumors

Risks of anesthesia and surgery in general are: - Problems breathing - Reactions to medicines - Bleeding, blood clots, infection Risks of surgery of the head and face are: - Nerve (cranial nerve dysfunction) or brain damage - Need for follow-up surgery, especially in growing children - Partial or total loss of bone grafts - Permanent scarring These complications are more common in people who: - Smoke - Have poor nutrition - Have other medical conditions, such as lupus - Have poor blood circulation - Have past nerve damage
People who have had a serious injury often need to work through the emotional issues of the trauma and the change in their appearance.
Children and adults who have had a serious injury may have post-traumatic stress disorder, depression, and anxiety disorders.
Parents of children with deformities of the face often feel guilty or ashamed, especially when the deformities are due to a genetic condition.
